awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Summer Research Projects in Neuroscience
awd_abstract_narration:
This REU Site award to the University of Missouri, Columbia, MU, will support the training of 10 students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2021-2023. It is anticipated that a total of 30 students, primarily from schools with limited research opportunities or from an under-represented group, will be trained in the program. The goal is to recruit 90% of the students from non-PhD granting institutions. Students from underrepresented groups are encouraged to apply. Students will learn how research is conducted, and many will present the results of their work at scientific conferences. Assessment of the program will be done through the online SALG URSSA tool. Students will be tracked after the program in order to determine their career paths.

This REU Site will train undergraduates in interdisciplinary neuroscience, with a focus on computational methods. The program starts with a one-week boot-camp on computational tools and technical writing. Neuroscience faculty members from the Colleges of Arts & Science, Engineering, Vet Med, and Medicine train undergraduates in research, in projects that range across the neuroscience spectrum, e.g., neuronal homeostasis and compensation (intracellular), mechanisms of exocytosis (cellular), fear memory formation in amygdala (cellar and network), cortico-basal ganglia system (network/systems), attention in human cognition (cognitive), and neural processing of motivated behaviors (behavioral). Additional projects are described in the program website. Faculty select candidates from the applicant pool, with the PI and his team approving the final selections based on best fit to the program. REU students are required to complete the responsible conduct of research (RCR) training online via the CITI site. The campus Office of Undergraduate Research offers a series of educational enrichment activities to enhance student skills. REU students are expected to attend an average of 3 hours/week of educational enrichment activities and class discussions, including RCR. More information about the program is available by visiting https://engineering.missouri.edu/academics/eecs/neuro/neuro-research/neuro-nsf-reu/
or by contacting the PI (Dr. Satish S.Nair at nairs@missouri.edu) or the co-PI (Dr. David Schulz at schulzd@missouri.edu).This award is supported by the Department of Defense ASSURE program thru a partnership with the NSF REU program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
Our REU program included a strong interdisciplinary team of faculty mentors with expertise at all levels in the growing field of neuroscience (intracellular/ cellular, systems and behavioral levels).

The specific objectives of our NSF REU Site on Neuroscience were to:

  • Introduce undergraduate students to the basics of the research process;
  • Demonstrate the importance of interaction (teamwork) and the value of different disciplines in collaborative research in neurosciences;
  • Introduce students to the intensity of specialized independent research without losing sight of how their work fits into the larger goals that brought such a diverse group of faculty together;
  • Foster students’ creativity and provide satisfaction from seeing successful results;
  • Develop outstanding candidates with research experience for graduate programs; and
  • Provide valuable experience in technical writing and oral presentations.

The key outcomes were as follows:

1.  All 30 students enrolled over the three years were from outside MU, based on an average of 134 applicants each year to an area that perceived as being difficult due to the need for a background of math and biology; The program was unique in the fact that neuroscience covers several levels of inquiry from genetic to molecular, cellular, systems, behavioral and clinical levels. So, the students and mentors came from multiple departments (over 10) spread over several colleges. For the students, this provides a unique interdisciplinary training ground to learn about the advances in the problem- and data- rich and growing area of neuroscience. Such an interdisciplinary-training is very beneficial for them at this early stage of their careers. 

2.  The 30 REU Fellows were from 19 different states in US, and from diverse departments: Biology (10), Neuroscience (9), Biochemistry (2), Psychology (5), Engineering (1), Computer Science (1), Cognitive Science (1) and Mathematics (1). Average GPA for the 30 Fellows was a high 3.69/4.  

3.  The representation from 19 different states and 8 different majors over the three years was as follows: Women = 70% (21 total; 5 African American; 4 Hispanic; 10 White Caucasian; 2 Asian-Pacific Islander);  Men = 27% (8 total; 1 African American, 1 Hispanic, 6 White Caucasian); Third Gender = 3% (1 total; 1 Hispanic). So, under-represented minorities, not counting women, were 11/30 or 36% of the total. Not counting URMs, 90% of the recruited students were from non-PhD granting institutions, exceeding our target of 75%.

  1. To date, the 2019-24 site program attendees have been co-authors on 2 journal articles and 7 national/ international conference papers/posters. We note that a third of the REU students completed their internship only end of Summer’24, and manuscripts including them could appear later.

5.  Of the 30 REU participants over 3 years, based on information available, a total of 3 have completed graduate programs (1 MS and 2 PhD),  3 are on-going in their PhD programs and 8 are yet to complete their BS program with several among them intending on applying to graduate programs. Three of those who completed the graduate programs included 1 African American and 2 Hispanic students. We note that a third of the REU students finished their internship only end of Summer’24, and they are yet to apply to grad programs.

6.  This has also had a positive effect on campus: (a) Faculty from over 10 departments are encouraging their undergraduates to take advantage of the new Interdisciplinary undergraduate minor in computational neuroscience between the Colleges of Arts & Science and Engineering, founded by PI Nair and Co-PI Schulz in 2012. Also, certificate programs in neuroscience are being developed (including by the PI) in multiple colleges; (b) Our biology research faculty are increasingly incorporating computational elements into their own research – 3 new during this period, and we hope to increase it to 6. (c) The PI also received another NSF award (OAC-1730655; 2017-2020; with Co-PI Calyam) to develop software automation training modules for data-intensive neuroscience learning and research. Together with a colleague, the PI Nair has developed a novel online MS program in Neural Engineering with its launch planned for Fall 2025, again benefiting from the past REU grants. The past REU site awards have benefited curriculum development also, and in turn, they helped us strengthen the REU program via improved as well as new training content, e.g., the software automation and AI components.

 


Last Modified: 01/25/2025
Modified by: Satish S Nair
